newsitem.title: UK: Trade union returns to Britain's GCHQ 13 years on.
newsitem.headline: Trade union returns to Britain's GCHQ 13 years on.

text.p: Trade unionists have returned to Britain's GCHQ government communications centre -- at the behest of a private company.

The GMB union announced on Friday, 13 years after then Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher banned staff at the intelligence listening post from union membership, that it had agreed union recognition of 182 of the more than 4,000 workers.

Its new members work for Vosper-ManTech, a joint venture between Vosper Thornycroft Holdings Plc and ManTech Advanced Systems International, which last year won the contract for outsourcing of GCHQ's engineering and logistics services.
"GCHQ suggested they be represented by the staff council body, but Vosper-Mantech said "No, we want a proper trade union'" GMB press officer Phil Woolas told journalists.
But he said staff still directly employed by GCHQ were still banned from union activities -- a situation which is expected to change if the opposition Labour party wins the upcoming election.
